title: NIRO
description: a checklist to allow reproducibile and open systematic review of non-intervention research

items.name: Describe the topic

content.general: Please give a short description of your review topic.

items.rationale: A short description enables readers to ascertain whether the framework for the project has shifted substantially between the protocol document and the systematic review.

items.name: Statement of need

content.general:
Why is the review needed?
* No previous review
* Update to previous review
* Previous reviews are flawed

items.rationale: A systematic review fits within the context of a literature of reviews, and its place in relation to existing reviews should be clarified.

items.name: Justification

content.general: Please provide a rationale for the review. Explain how the review will support the field of research and how the review will fit into the progress of research in the field.

items.rationale: A systematic review is a substantial undertaking, and thus a clear justification is important before beginning.

items.name: Identify the research question

content.general:
State the primary review question. Make sure it is clearly defined and includes:
* The primary effect of interest
* The independent variable(s) of interest
* The population of interest (e.g. general public, children, clinical patients)
* _Covariates of interest_

items.rationale: Identifying the primary review question before embarking on review keeps the project manageable and provides clarity for readers comparing the review to its protocol declaration.

items.name: _Identify the secondary questions_

content.general: _If applicable, identify secondary questions such as sources of heterogeneity within identified studies._

items.rationale: Secondary questions may arise during the process of systematic review. Declaring secondary questions identified before review begins allows them to be differentiated from exploratory questions prompted by the review process.

items.name: Statement of hypothesis

content.general: Clearly state the hypothesis for each question, and specify if the anticipated effect has a directionality (i.e. a one-tailed versus two-tailed hypothesis).

items.rationale: Stating hypotheses clearly before searches are made helps to ensure that tests of those hypotheses are more adequately representative of true effects.

items.name: Include a descriptive title

content.general: A systematic review should have a descriptive title which clearly identifies the research question and the methodology (systematic review).
content.author: Give your systematic review a descriptive title which clearly identifies the research question and the methodology (systematic review).
content.reviewer: The systematic review a should have a descriptive title which clearly identifies the research question and the methodology (systematic review).

items.rationale:
Including information about the methodology in the title enables rapid identification of systematic reviews.

This can really help for projects compiling systematic reviews, and also for projects which need to exclude them such as meta analyses.

items.name: Search syntax

content.general: A systematic review should include the full search strategy string from each database searched.
content.author: Please include the full search strategy string from each database searched. This should be specified in the protocol.
content.reviewer: The systematic review should include the full search strategy string from each database searched. This should be specified in the protocol.

items.rationale: Including the specific search string allows other researchers to fully reproduce the methodology, and allows reviewers to identify possible omissions such as alternate terms from adjacent fields.

items.name: Search date

content.general: A systematic review should include the date the search was conducted for each database searched. If multiple searches are conducted on a single database, dates should be included for all searches.
content.author: State the date each database was searched. If multiple searches are conducted on a single database, dates should be included for all searches.
content.reviewer: The systematic review should include the date each database was searched. If multiple searches on a single database are mentioned, dates should be included for all searches.

items.rationale: Including the search dates allows other researchers to determine which studies are likely to have been available at the time of review.

items.name: Grey literature

content.general: A systematic review should include an explanation of how unpublished or inaccessible information was approached. Was any attempt made to locate and access information which was not formally published in accessible locations?
content.author: Give a summary of your attempts to obtain unpublished/inaccessible papers or additional materials and whether this was successful.
content.reviewer: The systematic review should include an explanation of how unpublished or inaccessible information was approached.

items.rationale: Studies which have null results often remain unpublished [file drawer problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Publication_bias), which can skew otherwise-balanced attempts to aggregate information. Some reviews attempt to combat this by contacting authors to ask for unpublished work, following up search results for conference posters and presentations, etc. This _grey literature_ search can help to redress publication bias.
